Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 37909-033 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
September 2021 
 
 
Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration 
through Knowledge and Capacity Building of Trade 
and Supply Chain Finance Program Banks 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This is the version of the document approved by ADB’s Board of Directors that excludes 
information that is subject to exceptions to disclosure set forth in ADB's Access to Information 
Policy. 
 
 
 
 
PUBLIC. This information is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ADF  –  Asian Development Fund 
DMC  –  developing member country 
SCFP  –  Supply Chain Finance Program 
TA  –  technical assistance 
TFP  –  Trade Finance Program 
TSCFP  –  Trade and Supply Chain Finance Program 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars unless otherwise stated 
.

TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE 
 
 
PPUUBBLLIICC..  TThhiiss  iinnffoorrmmaattiioonn  iiss  bbeeiinngg  ddiisscclloosseedd  ttoo  tthhee  ppuubblliicc  iinn  aaccccoorrddaannccee  wwiitthh  AADDBB’’ss  AAcccceessss  ttoo  IInnffoorrmmaattiioonn  PPoolliiccyy..

I.  THE ONGOING PROGRAM 
 
1.  ADB’s Trade Finance Program (TFP) fills market gaps for trade finance by providing 
guarantees, loans, and risk participation products (both funded and unfunded) to banks to support 
trade. It works with over 260 partner banks and operates in 21 developing member countries 
(DMCs). Since inception, it is estimated that TFP has supported almost 20,000 small and medium-
sized enterprises (SMEs) through over 34,000 transactions valued at over $48 billion. In 2020, 
the number of transactions supported by TFP increased by 49%, to 7,178 from 4,832 in 2019. 
The value of transactions grew by 7%, to $5.8 billion from $5.4 billion in 2019. O 
  
2.  The Supply Chain Finance Program (SCFP) works with corporates and partner financial 
institutions (PFIs) to enhance the access of SMEs to working capital and operates in 10 DMCs. 
In 2020, the number of transactions supported by SCFP increased by 151% to 1,447 while the 
value of those transactions increased by 108% to $246 million. Of the 1,447 transactions in 2020, 
676 were estimated to support SMEs, a 51% increase over 2019.  
 
3.  The two programs are complementary and were re-branded in 2020 into the Trade and 
Supply Chain Finance Program (TSCFP) to leverage on TFP’s existing relationships and achieve 
operational efficiencies and provide better client service. TSCFP is ADB’s largest program and 
generator of co-financing, contributing a total of $3.1 billion short-term co-financing in 2020. 
Meanwhile, total TSCFP commitments amounted to $2.9 billion in the same year.   
 
4.  TSCFP  is  central  to  ADB’s  response  to  the  COVID-19  pandemic.1 Of  the  7,178 
transactions supported under TFP, 5,467 were COVID-related transactions worth $4.5 billion for 
the purchase of goods such as test kits and medical equipment. These supported (i) companies 
that provide essential services and (ii) financial intermediaries that provide direct financing to 
individual companies, including SMEs, or facilitate local, regional, and global trade and related 
supply chains that have been materially affected by the pandemic’s economic fallout. Of the 1,447 
transactions supported under SCFP, 1,288 were COVID-related transactions worth $211 million. 
Of this, 1,058 transactions valued at $185 million provided support to the pharmaceutical sector, 
with a particular focus on SMEs. Transactions to support the purchase and delivery of COVID-19 
vaccines are being considered as part of the SCFP’s 2021 operations.2  
 
5.  TSCFP also encourages commercial sustainability by promoting sustainability in trade, 
ensuring integrity and transparency, as well as helping accelerate progress in gender equality. In 
addition, TSCFP started supply chain finance capacity building activities in Georgia and produced 
targeted knowledge products such as the COVID-19 supply chain tool,3 webinars about managing 
COVID-19 trade finance risk and digitization, SCFP webinars, and enhanced online training. In 
2020, TSCFP conducted 10 webinars with over 1,200 participants.  
 
 
1   ADB. 2020. ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic. Manila. 
2   In December 2020, a $500 million Vaccine Import Facility under the existing TFP program limit was developed to help developing 
economies in Asia and the Pacific purchase vaccines and related equipment needed to fight COVID-19. The facility provides 
guarantees through the program’s network of partner banks to support the purchase of vaccines, as well as glass vials, syringes, 
and equipment for cold chain storage facilities. Through risk sharing with partner banks, the $500 million facility can be leveraged 
to $1 billion.  
3   A new tool https://www.adb.org/multimedia/scf/ was launched by TSCFP in May 2020 and published on the ADB website that maps, 
end-to-end, the entire supply chain for 33 critical pandemic-fighting goods, such as ventilators, N95 masks, etc. The tool helps 
banks, investors and governments to ensure that companies have no bottlenecks and that financial support is there to ramp up 
supply.  
 
PUBLIC. This information is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information Policy.

2   
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
6.  The Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility and the Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Fund (RCIF) aim to (i) improve cross-border physical connectivity; 
(ii) increase trade and investment flows in DMCs from regional and nonregional economies, and 
(iii) preserve macroeconomic and financial stability in the region, among other goals. TSCFP 
helps fulfil those aims by boosting trade, including among DMCs, and by building capacity in the 
region so that DMCs can take advantage of global supply chains. More trade leads to increased 
economic growth and jobs, cementing economic stability throughout the region.  
 
7.  Trade finance is explicitly recognized in the Addis Ababa Action Agenda on Financing for 
Development as an important means of implementing the Sustainable Development Goals 
(SDGs).4 However, according to an ADB survey published in September 2019, the global trade 
finance gap was $1.5 trillion, with more than 40% of rejected trade finance transactions coming 
from SMEs. Lowering the trade finance gap would help achieve SDGs, including those related to 
gender equality and economic growth.5 Thus, ADB, in accordance with Strategy 2030, will expand 
the use and reach of the TSCFP.6  
 
8.  The COVID-19 pandemic poses an immense challenge for many DMCs. It underscores 
the need for critical trade support not only to move medical supplies but also to bolster economies. 
Regional cooperation is necessary to exchange knowledge, identify supply and financing gaps, 
and mobilize resources. TSCFP’s high visibility, constant engagement with clients and delivery of 
knowledge products helps foster regional cooperation and integration. It is an excellent crisis 
response vehicle, with a global network of PFIs through which support can be channeled quickly 
and efficiently, including to SMEs impacted by the pandemic. 
 
9.  The proposed $1.25 million technical assistance (TA)7 will help TSCFP reduce market 
gaps for trade finance. The TA will fund the engagement of consultants (i) for business operations 
and administration to manage growing volumes, thereby complementing existing staff resources, 
and (ii) for various capacity building initiatives such as enhanced sustainability/safeguards, 
integrity due diligence, and gender policies. To further close gaps, promote regional cooperation 
and integration and as a tool to address the pandemic, the TA will fund delivery of knowledge 
products, services, and solution in addition to transactions. 
 
10.  Sustainability Initiatives. The TA will build on work done under previous TFP TAs to 
create more awareness of and help address social and environmental issues such as child/forced 
labor, climate change and sustainability through the banking sector, which is expected to also 
impact banks’ clients, including SMEs.8 TSCFP will conduct safeguards training and webinars to 
deepen its partner banks’ awareness and understanding of environmental and social safeguards 
and enhance their safeguards capacity. 
 
 
4  United Nations. 2015. Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development. Addis 
Ababa. 
5   ADB. 2019. Trade Finance Gaps, Growth and Jobs Survey. ADB Briefs. No. 113. Manila:  
6   ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
7   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on XXX (to be filled in after approval). 
8  ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance for Capacity Development for Expansion of the Trade Finance Program into the Pacific and 
Enhanced Safeguards and Integrity Measures for Trade Finance Program Banks. ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance for Capacity 
Building for Enhanced Safeguards, Anti-Corruption and Integrity Measures, Gender Equity Policies and Digitization of Trade 
Finance Program Banks. Manila. 
 
PUBLIC. This information is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information Policy.

3 
11.  Anticorruption  and  Integrity  Measures.  Unintended  consequences  of  anti-money-
laundering and counter-financing of terrorism (AML/CFT) measures contribute to market gaps. 
The TA will support strengthening of AML/CFT practices by funding related online training and 
preparation for the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) Working Group on Trade-Based Money 
Laundering events in various DMCs. It will also improve monitoring of such issues by conducting 
integrity due diligence reviews on all TSCFP partner banks and financial institutions. 
 
12.  Gender Initiatives. The TSCFP’s gender initiative is in progress with human resource 
policies of 19 partner banks in 8 DMCs reviewed to identify enhancements to attract, retain, 
and promote women in banking.9  Consultants will be engaged to implement future phases of this 
initiative  including  expanding  to  more  banks  in  more  DMCs,  implement  complex 
recommendations, develop, and implement guidelines, knowledge products or events for partner 
banks on gender-related safeguard issues.  
 
13.  Other Capacity Building and Knowledge Initiatives. The TA will fund other online 
training, regional conferences, webinars, and physical training and seminars, if possible post-
pandemic for DMC banks, SMEs, and government agencies, on topics related to trade and supply 
chain finance. TSCFP will continue its Twinning Program, which brings banks together within the 
region to leverage their respective expertise and strengths to share and transfer knowledge. The 
TA will also fund TSCFP’s Annual Awards and networking event that recognizes the most active 
banks in trade finance, SME support, sustainable transactions, and gender initiatives.  
 
14.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030 and  promotes Operational  Priority G: 
Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration Pillar 2 Global and regional trade and investment 
opportunities  expanded  through  trade.10 Through  TSCFP’s  gender  equity  and  safeguards 
initiatives, the TA supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities B, C and D. The proposed 
capacity building and knowledge-sharing activities under the TA demonstrate ADB’s role as a 
knowledge institution and knowledge provider. The TA also promotes ADB’s Strategy 2030 key 
operational priorities F related to strengthening governance and institutional capacity. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
15.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table 1.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,250,000, of which (i) $250,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Financial  Sector  Development  Partnership  Special  Fund  (FSDPSF)11 and  (ii) 
$1,000,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.12 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. PSOD will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 2. 
 
 
11 Established by ADB. Financing partner: the Government of Luxembourg. 
12 Established by ADB. Financing partner: the Government of Japan.

18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.13  
 
19.  Co-financier requirements. For FSDPSF, TSCFP will provide semi-annual progress 
reports by each 31 July and 31 January, and additional updates as necessary on project 
implementation. For RCIF, TSCFP will provide annual progress reports of project implementation, 
and updates any material changes in scope and/or implementation arrangements. 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,250,000 on a grant basis for 
Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration Through Knowledge and Capacity Building of 
Trade and Supply Chain Finance Program Banks, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
 
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). ADB may consider output-based 
or lump sum consultant contracts when deemed more appropriate and depending on the nature of the assignment and TOR will be 
revised accordingly. 
 
PUBLIC. This information is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information Policy.
